[p][b]Pain relief[/b] can be described as an effect which suppresses negative sensations such as aches and pains. This can occur through a variety of different pharmacological and subjective mechanisms such as blocking the physical sensations from reaching one's conscious faculties, by covering the sensation with feelings of physical and cognitive euphoria, or by directly targetting the body part which the sensation is arising from.[/p]

[p]Pain relief is often accompanied by other coinciding effects such as [int-link to="/effects/muscle-relaxation"]muscle relaxation[/int-link], [int-link to="/effects/physical-euphoria"]physical euphoria[/int-link], and [int-link to="/effects/sedation"]sedation[/int-link]. It is most commonly induced under the influence of moderate dosages of a very wide variety of compounds, such as opioids, GABAergics, GABApentinoids, cannabinoids, [int-link to="/summaries/dissociatives"]dissociatives[/int-link], muscle relaxants, and NSAIDs.[/p]

It is most commonly induced under the influence of moderate dosages of a very wide variety of compounds, such as opioids, GABAergics, GABApentinoids, cannabinoids, dissociatives, muscle relaxants, and NSAID's.
